_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Edison site, has a Risk Management Program which meets the requirements of OSHA-PSM, EPA-RMP,
New Jersey-TCPA and the ACC-Responsible Care guidelines. The site is a OSHA VPP Star site and it's Quality
and Environmental management systems are certified for ISO 9001 and ISO 14001 standards.

The Process Safety Information documentation and updating functions are assigned to different department
managers and are detailed in the "Site Employee Participation Plan"document.

Process Hazard Analysis are conducted on a five year schedule by suitable process hazard analysis teams. The
teams are composed of a team leader, various personnel having knowledge of production and maintenance procedures,
and a prodcution operator. Normally the HAZOP and What If / Checklist methods are used. The completion of
recommendations are tracted by an electronic data base. The Process and Quality (PQC) Manager is responsible
for implementation of this RMP element.

The Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) are written and updated by the process and production engineers / 
supervisors. The Production Manager is responsible for keeping SOP's current. The SOP's are verified and certified for
correctness once a year. The SOP's are available to relevant personnel via a LAN system and a "hard copy" of each
SOP is available in the applicable production area.

The training is planned and tracted by the Safety and Training Manager according to the annual training plan.
The training materials include manuals, lesson plans, video tapes, overheads and field equipment. The understanding
of the training is verrified by written tests, oral exams and demonstrations. Any one or all of these may be employed.
The training activities are tracked by a training database.

The Engineering Manager is responsible for implementation of the Mechanical Integrity Program. The program
consists of program manual, equipment lists and specifications, equipment history files, preventive maintenance
procedures and an automated

work order system. Work permits, entry permits, and hot work permits have been 
incorporated in the Safety Procedures Manual. Yearly reports are issed to verify that all regulated equipment is 
testedand inspected as per the documented program.

The Safety and Training Manager is responsible for implementation of the Management Of Change (MOC) Program.
The detailed MOC procedure and the Pre-Startup Procedure have been incorporated in the Safety Procedures 
manual. A committee consisting of various technical personnel reviews and approves all MOC requests. The 
completion of all action items is tracked and documented via an electronic database system.

Annual and tri-annual compliance audits are coordinated by the PQC Manager. Normally they are led by corporate
expert personnel. Deficiencies are noted and scheduled for system improvements by the responsible managers.
The completion of recommendationsis tracked and documented via electronic database.

The Incident Investigation Program consists of a detailed procedure incorporated in the Safety Procedures Manual.
All regulated chemical releases are investigated by the area supervisor by forming an incident investigation team 
and issued as preliminary reports to a review committee. The committee reviews the reports to ensure that root causes have been identified and suitable corrective actions have been proposed. The Safety and Training Manager then issues a final 
incident investigation report by incorporating information and feedback from all sources and reviews. The final report is 
distributed to all supervisory personnel, who in turn discusses it with all employees in their periodic safety contacts meeting. 
All action items are tracked and the completion is documented via an electronic database system.

There is a written Emplyee Participation Plan document, which describes the major requirements of various RMP 
elements and how the employees participate in their implementation. The program is implemented by th

e PQC
Manager.

The Contractor Program follows the OSHA-PSM and NJ-TCPA requirements. The program is implemented by the 
Safety and Training Manger.

Site release prevention and chemical specific prevention used include relief valves, rupture disks, vents, check valves, scrubbers,
quench systems, automatic shutoffs, interlocks, keyed bypasses, grounding, and purge systems.  Mitigation systems used are dikes, sprinkler systems, deluge systems, water curtains, hazmat foam system, fire fighting foam system, mineral oil dump systems, and nuetralization. Most of the process areas are monitored by leak detection and alarm systems for toxic and flammable gas leaks.  Operator refresher tranining is conducted on prescribed basis of the operator tranining program. The preventitive maintenance program conducts inspections and tests to assure operation of preventive devices.  Manangement of change procedures assures that all changes are reviwed for theior hazards before implementation. All incidents are investigated to determine root cause and corrective actions are implemented to prevent future incidents.

The site had no reportable accident during the last five years.

The site emergency response program meets the requirments of the EPA Integrated Contingency Plan Guidance. The plan defines the response organization, coordination with local emergency response committee, equipment, response procedures, training, notification procedures, and drills. The plan is updated acording to the recommendations from system deficiencies uncovered by the perioidic drills and he incident reports.
